seg-source.mrk: collation=collation attribute

target.mrk: collation=collation attribute

seg-source.mrk: collation

target.mrk: collation

seg-source.mrk: database attribute

target.mrk: database attribute

seg-source.mrk: database attribute

seg-source.mrk: collation

seg-source.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED

target.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED

seg-source.mrk: collation attribute

target.mrk: collation attribute

seg-source.mrk: Function

target.mrk: Function

trans-unit.source: The collation=collation attribute is an optional attribute that specifies whether collation is based on the locale specified for the database or on Unicode codepoint collation. The valid values for the collation=collation attribute are:

seg-source.mrk: The collation=collation attribute is an optional attribute that specifies whether collation is based on the locale specified for the database or on Unicode codepoint collation.
The valid values for the collation=collation attribute are:

target.mrk: The collation=collation attribute is an optional attribute that specifies whether collation is based on the locale specified for the database or on Unicode codepoint collation.
The valid values for the collation=collation attribute are:

seg-source.mrk: UCS_BASIC

target.mrk: UCS_BASIC

trans-unit.source: Unicode codepoint collation. This value is the default.

seg-source.mrk: Unicode codepoint collation.
This value is the default.

target.mrk: Unicode codepoint collation.
This value is the default.

seg-source.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED

target.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED

trans-unit.source: Based on the language specified with the territory=ll_CC attribute. The default collation strength for the locale is used. The default for is commonly TERTIARY, in which character case is significant in searches and comparisons.

seg-source.mrk: Based on the language specified with the territory=ll_CC attribute.
The default collation strength for the locale is used.
The default for <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> is commonly TERTIARY, in which character case is significant in searches and comparisons.

target.mrk: Based on the language specified with the territory=ll_CC attribute.
The default collation strength for the locale is used.
The default for <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> is commonly TERTIARY, in which character case is significant in searches and comparisons.

seg-source.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED:PRIMARY

target.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED:PRIMARY

trans-unit.source: Locale based with collation strength PRIMARY. Specify this value to make <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> behave similarly to many other databases, for which PRIMARY is commonly the default. PRIMARY typically means that only differences in base letters are considered significant, whereas differences in accents or case are not considered significant.

seg-source.mrk: Locale based with collation strength PRIMARY.
Specify this value to make <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> behave similarly to many other databases, for which PRIMARY is commonly the default.
PRIMARY typically means that only differences in base letters are considered significant, whereas differences in accents or case are not considered significant.

target.mrk: Locale based with collation strength PRIMARY.
Specify this value to make <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> behave similarly to many other databases, for which PRIMARY is commonly the default.
PRIMARY typically means that only differences in base letters are considered significant, whereas differences in accents or case are not considered significant.

seg-source.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED:SECONDARY

target.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED:SECONDARY

trans-unit.source: Locale based with collation strength SECONDARY. SECONDARY typically means that differences in base letters or accents are considered significant, whereas differences in case are not considered significant.

seg-source.mrk: Locale based with collation strength SECONDARY.
SECONDARY typically means that differences in base letters or accents are considered significant, whereas differences in case are not considered significant.

target.mrk: Locale based with collation strength SECONDARY.
SECONDARY typically means that differences in base letters or accents are considered significant, whereas differences in case are not considered significant.

seg-source.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED:TERTIARY

target.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED:TERTIARY

trans-unit.source: Locale based with collation strength TERTIARY. TERTIARY typically means that differences in base letters, accents, or case are all considered significant.

seg-source.mrk: Locale based with collation strength TERTIARY.
TERTIARY typically means that differences in base letters, accents, or case are all considered significant.

target.mrk: Locale based with collation strength TERTIARY.
TERTIARY typically means that differences in base letters, accents, or case are all considered significant.

seg-source.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED:IDENTICAL

target.mrk: TERRITORY_BASED:IDENTICAL

trans-unit.source: Locale based with collation strength IDENTICAL. IDENTICAL means that all differences are considered significant.

seg-source.mrk: Locale based with collation strength IDENTICAL.
IDENTICAL means that all differences are considered significant.

target.mrk: Locale based with collation strength IDENTICAL.
IDENTICAL means that all differences are considered significant.

trans-unit.source: The collation=collation attribute can be specified only when you create a database. You cannot specify this attribute on an existing database or when you upgrade a database.

seg-source.mrk: The collation=collation attribute can be specified only when you create a database.
You cannot specify this attribute on an existing database or when you upgrade a database.

target.mrk: The collation=collation attribute can be specified only when you create a database.
You cannot specify this attribute on an existing database or when you upgrade a database.

trans-unit.source: If you specify the collation=collation attribute with the value TERRITORY_BASED, or one of its variants with a specific collation strength, the collation is based on the language and country codes that you specify with the territory=ll_CC attribute.

seg-source.mrk: If you specify the collation=collation attribute with the value TERRITORY_BASED, or one of its variants with a specific collation strength, the collation is based on the language and country codes that you specify with the territory=ll_CC attribute.

target.mrk: If you specify the collation=collation attribute with the value TERRITORY_BASED, or one of its variants with a specific collation strength, the collation is based on the language and country codes that you specify with the territory=ll_CC attribute.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify the territory=ll_CC attribute when you create the database, uses the java.util.Locale.getDefault method to determine the current value of the default locale for this instance of the Java Virtual Machine (JVM).

seg-source.mrk: If you do not specify the territory=ll_CC attribute when you create the database, uses the java.util.Locale.getDefault method to determine the current value of the default locale for this instance of the Java Virtual Machine (JVM).

target.mrk: If you do not specify the territory=ll_CC attribute when you create the database, uses the java.util.Locale.getDefault method to determine the current value of the default locale for this instance of the Java Virtual Machine (JVM).

trans-unit.source: The collation=collation attribute applies only to user-defined tables. The system tables use the Unicode codepoint collation.

seg-source.mrk: The collation=collation attribute applies only to user-defined tables.
The system tables use the Unicode codepoint collation.

target.mrk: The collation=collation attribute applies only to user-defined tables.
The system tables use the Unicode codepoint collation.

trans-unit.source: For information on how <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> handles collation, see "Creating a database with locale-based collation" and "Character-based collation in <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

seg-source.mrk: For information on how <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> handles collation, see "Creating a database with locale-based collation" and "Character-based collation in <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

target.mrk: For information on how <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> handles collation, see "Creating a database with locale-based collation" and "Character-based collation in <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph>.

seg-source.mrk: Example

target.mrk: Example

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the URL to create the MexicanDB database. The territory=ll_CC attribute specifies Spanish for the language code and Mexico for the country code. The collation=collation attribute specifies that the collation for the database is locale based.

seg-source.mrk: The following example shows the URL to create the MexicanDB database.
The territory=ll_CC attribute specifies Spanish for the language code and Mexico for the country code.
The collation=collation attribute specifies that the collation for the database is locale based.

target.mrk: The following example shows the URL to create the MexicanDB database.
The territory=ll_CC attribute specifies Spanish for the language code and Mexico for the country code.
The collation=collation attribute specifies that the collation for the database is locale based.

seg-source.mrk: jdbc:derby:MexicanDB;create=true;territory=es_MX;collation=TERRITORY_BASED

target.mrk: jdbc:derby:MexicanDB;create=true;territory=es_MX;collation=TERRITORY_BASED
